text: Healthcare Professional: Oh they thought it was N___’s car. Doctor: He sort of - sent the text out as if it was his car with a picture of my car. HCP OH! Family Member: His car. Oh my! Doctor: But now he doesn’t have any car because he’s in college. He doesn’t have - HCP Oh okay! Family Member: The Mercedes Patient: He’s lucky he’s having college paid for. Doctor: Yeah I know. text: Patient: And that’s what is kind of annoying you know that - Doctor: Yeah, that we could not have continued it. Patient: At least - Doctor: But you really had a off-the-chart benefit with that. Okay. Agreed. Patient: And if I had you know two more treatments, would it have been enough you know? Doctor: I don’t know. Patient: But where do you draw the line as to how much you can take, you know? Well - Doctor: I don’t know. Well, that’s the problem. Patient: It didn’t affect me Doctor: Safety-wise, right now it’s only six months, you know. And there are some unexpected effects that are coming out for radium with um Zytiga because people have had, well there’s no problems with just adding the radium- Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: on top of the Zytiga. Now two/three years later, the study that they did of the combination is reporting way more factures and issues. Family Member: OOH!

text: Patient: You know, I feel good. Doctor: That’s good. Let’s see and you’re sixty… Patient: No I’m fifty-nine. Doctor: Fifty-nine. Patient: I’m not sixty yet. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: It’s alright. text: Family Member: Okay. I heard Doctor: Well, BRCA2 also puts you at risk for melanoma, so. (pause) Patient: Well, I’ve got a lot of skin tags. So. text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Oxycodone immediate release five milligrams. Patient: No, that’s been set up for ten milligrams, and that’s as needed now after it’s been about two weeks since my radiation. Doctor: So it’s that ten milligram pill you take? Patient: No it’s two fives. Doctor: Oh, yeah. The OxyContin? And the OxyContin is thirty milligrams twice a day? Patient: Once a day; I’m taking it once a day now. Doctor: Once a day. Patient: Yeah, I’m taking it at night, so you know to get ahead of the pain. But it’s been pretty good. I haven’t been in much hip pain lately, hardly at all. Doctor: The Simvastatin twenty milligrams a day. That’s your Zocor. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: Your Flomax or Tamsulosin once a day? Patient: Yeah.

text: Patient: Oh, of course. Doctor: You know, so we want you to be ready. What I want is for that to be in your medicine cabinet. Family Member 1: If his gums are sensitive, can I call M___ too? Doctor: Yep, yes. And you know you could gargle with salt water to just keep that bacteria moving out of there. So there's no sort of overdose on warm saltwater. Family Member 1: How about hydrogen peroxide, diluted? Doctor: That's hard. Family Member 1: Oh okay. Doctor: See that's hard because any alcohol based products for our mouths are bad. Family Member 1: There’s alcohol, I forgot. Doctor: So it's a challenge for cancer patients. So like if you look at Listerine or Crest they have now the non alcohol version. So you could try that. Family Member 1: He likes to gargle with Listerine. Doctor: Yeah, there's a non alcohol version of Listerine.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
